(45) Moreover, there is only the Buddha's teachings for treating physical and mental illnesses. Therefore, one should diligently listen

When the great assembly saw this, they joined their palms in respect, their faith doubled, and they gave rise to something they had never had before, their body hairs standing on end. They then spoke a verse, saying:

The TathÄgata, in the past for billions of eons, practiced austerities. With this merit, he gathered this Dharma medicine of the twelve links of dependent origination, able to cause the hearer to weep with grief.

At that time, the prince, having regained his eyesight, was overjoyed. Hearing the Dharma and becoming disgusted with birth and death, he attained the fruit of stream-entry. Giving rise to a rare thought, he spoke a verse, saying:
Who, having heard the Buddha's Dharma, would not give rise to joy?
I have already deeply respected and believed, listening to the Dharma with utmost sincerity.
Hearing the rare events with the ears, the eye ailment has also been eliminated,

I now bow my head in respect to the most victorious among all physicians.

The Venerable ÅšÄkyamuni is the compassionate father of sentient beings,

Even the people of the borderlands can attain enlightenment.

Furthermore, if one attains the four unshakable confidences, one would rather give up one's life than harm the above objects. Therefore, one should diligently cultivate the four unshakable confidences.
I once heard that there was a criminal who was to be executed. At that time, a chandala was next in line to execute people.
That chandala was a lay disciple who had attained the path of seeing the truth, and was unwilling to kill people. The one in charge of executions became extremely angry and said to him:
Do you now wish to violate the king's laws and regulations?
The upasaka said to the one in charge of executions:
You are extremely ignorant. Why does the king insist on making me kill people?

Although his physical body belongs to the king and he is a candala, he was born in the lineage of the sages and is called the dharma body, which does not belong to the king and is not subject to the king's control.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The Venerable Shakyamuni, endowed with omniscience,

At that time, the one in charge of executions, because this person violated the king's prohibitions, took him to the king and said:
This candala does not follow the king's teachings.
The king said to him:
Why do you not follow the king's teachings?
He replied:
Great king!
You should now give rise to faith and a joyful mind.
And spoke a verse, saying:
Eliminating the defilements of the three poisons, obtaining the cause of quiescence,
The unsurpassed great compassion, the abode of the World-Honored One with the ten powers,
Upholding the precepts, even towards mosquitoes and ants,
Not giving rise to a harmful mind, let alone towards humans.
At that time, the king said:

This upÄsaka, with the power of seeing the truth, then confronted the king without difficulty and said:
This body belongs to the king, and the king has complete control over my body.
According to my intention, even if the emperor commands me, I will still not follow.
When the king heard these words, he became extremely angry and ordered the execution.

That caá¹‡á¸Äla's father and seven brothers all refused to kill. The king then killed them. There were two remaining. He ordered the sixth one to kill, but he also refused to kill, so the king killed him. He reached the seventh one, who also refused to kill, so the king killed him again.

The candala spoke like this, and the king gave rise to a determined intention, calling it the village of sages, not the candala. I am truly a candala.ğŸ”½I have no compassion or pity, and have killed a wise person out of extreme evil,

Who does not spare his own life, but protects the precepts and practices.
At that time, the king brought his many ministers, several billion Brahmins, and walked to the cemetery, saying:

Piling up the dead bodies, he shed tears for them. The king again spoke a verse, saying:
The one who is brave and upholds the precepts, with a sword cuts apart his body,
The corpse is left on the ground, and blood mud smears his body,
It is because of upholding the precepts that he gives up this body today.
With a firm mind, he does not commit evil, guarding the precepts until death,
One who obtains the taste of the Buddha's teachings, the wise should all be like this.
The king further spoke a verse, saying:
Blind with foolishness, defiled by the impurities of greed and desire,
Attached to the faculties of self and what belongs to self, agitated and unstable.
Not considering evil karma, only taking present happiness,

The body and wealth are thought of as fragile, also like trees on a riverbank,

At that time, the great king, out of respect for the Dharma, circumambulated the caá¹‡á¸Äla's body three times, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and spoke a verse, saying:

Even if one were to enter a forest of fire, seeing the truth and violating the precepts,
This would never happen - this is the clear evidence.
This person upholds the Buddha's words, never having two minds,
Lying in mud and blood, in order to protect the Buddha's precepts.

The Buddha said that seeing the truth will never be violated. The four elements can be destroyed, but the four unshakable confidences will never be destroyed.
47. Furthermore, if the mind is arrogant, no evil is not committed. Although arrogance is self-aggrandizing, it is called self-abasement. Therefore, one should eliminate arrogance.
